Well, here I am at the end. Not just of this series on games, but of Crash Course. Over the past 4 months, I've watched about 10 videos a day. This was the last video of the last completed series (meaning the only videos left are the series currently running). This show has really helped to provide structure and edification to my day as I continue to search for a job post-graduation (going on a year and a half!). Thank you for providing me with a sense of accomplishment with my mornings!
Thank you, Andre. I watched the series with great interest, though I'm sad there weren't more episodes on traditional games. But I've learned a lot and it was interesting to watch a series on games.
My second crash course is completed. Thank you, it was informative and interesting.

Sadly the future is more aggressive and predatory monitization and games designed to be less fun and more frustrating on purpose to turn players into payers.
The Games now play the Players, and the house wins by gambling mechanics.

Massive fallacy: video gaming increases all sorts of cognitive and problem-solving skills, yes, but in order go get to a point where that increase in skills becomes noteworthy, one needs to either have played for a very long time (by which point he/she will have missed the opportunity to utilize those skills in the real-world by spending all their free time on video games) or have started playing video games at a very early age (which again indicates that this person is likely to spend most of their life's free time playing deez games because early affinities tend to stay). Whichever way you look at it, gaming may be useful in all sorts of ways, but, on its own, it doesn't lead to anything but entertainment.
Excellent series! Super informative and interesting. Well done!!

Please do more crash course games. It's been 3 years since the last series, and a lot has happened since then. Also, this course of crash course games really focused on the big ideas of gaming. It would be nice to get a nother series at focuses on the small details. Like the history of console exclusivity. And maybe more of a focus on individual gaming titles that drove the future of video games.

The game industry is headed for another crash. Much like in 1983, publisher greed is slowly decaying away consumer confidence. Eventually, people are just not going to be interested in getting ripped off anymore. Indie gaming will always be around, but the industry as a whole is going to collapse. Once the government gets involved in regulating loot boxes, then it's all over.

Super disappointed by this series. Barely touched on ANYTHING but video games, a small category of a vast subject. It was not comprehensive, organized, or especially informative- especially when compared against other series. You should have just called it Crash Course Video Games, replaced the couple of non-VG episodes with something more relevant, and saved the rest of the topic for a more expansive discussion. A single episode of Extra Credits is more useful in understanding all of video games than this entire series was.

I was born in 1975 and I have seen a lot of video game highs and lows take place. From Pong to the video game crash of 1983, from the Nintendo vs. Sega slugfest of the 90's to the current high res systems of today. It has been an awesome ride, now looking forward to what video games and consoles will bless players with, in the years to come. For me, I would like to see more VR incorporated into the games I play.

Thank you Andre and Crash Course Games, it is an awesome series!
GG M8 EZ

No doubt we're becoming a society of gamers. But the average age of a gamer is absolutely NOT 31.

Most every poll of that nature counts 45 year olds whose only game is Candy Crush as a "gamer". But a gamer is not simply a person who plays a game sometimes. There's a culture and vernacular attached to it. Give some of those CandyCrushers a PS4 controller and what the confusion ensue. I'm getting really tired of people making this claim. The average age of a gamer is certainly closer to 25.
Please please please add more! There is so much more to talk about!  <3

It's telling that your image of the "average gamer" is a thirtysomething white man named Steve. In the communities I hang out in, "Steve" is a derogatory term for the default protagonist of today's big-budget video games--a thirtysomething white man with something to prove at everyone else's expense, like Nathan Drake, Desmond in Assassin's Creed, and basically the entire cast of Quantum break. Steves are homogeneous and forgettable, and they do not represent gaming and gamers as a whole, especially not if you include female-dominated areas of gaming like mobile games as a kind of game--which I'm pretty sure you are because you did a whole episode on it..

Andre, you have committed the cardinal sin. You have forgotten to mention NIntendo. Never, ever, forget Nintendo when talking about the future of games. They're the ones who steer the ship. They resurrected the game industry. They brought it into 3d right. They brought us motion controls. Now they are going to completely change the way we play games with the switch, where there is no longer really defined platforms of handheld or console anymore.

I would say Overwatch has quite a bit story telling weaved in to it. But is not a traditional liner narrative you usually find in media. Much of it even happens outside the game. But it is there. There slowly building this world for the players and that is part of is great appeal. In a sense battlefront lives on this sort of narrative to. The game would most likely not sell even half as well if it was not for the mythos of Star Wars.

AI. For the love of god can some studio (or google) actually make a decent Ai rather than rely on graphics. I don't even care about VR - gaming AI IS the final frontier.

Yes they will stupidly try to increase iteration cycles for consoles,
But this will not have the result they intended in the long run.
there are secondary factors that make this viable with phones, and they could get away with it to a degree on handhelds, but NOT for home systems.
they will try they will fail, then with luck they will see it is not the platform but the game that is important and put focus into creating a better experience, not just cycling the hardware to do more complex or detailed things.

Episodic games can be good, but in most cases, it is just an unjustified cash grab.

First things first: this was a very good series. Well played!
Second: This happened to Rock music, movies and now it is happening to videogames; the nostalgia effect is enormous. First the infustry stablishes its classics. Then the number of subgenres keeps rising. The means of production get gradually available for more and more people. The classics emerge as common ancestors and/or shared knowledge, getting more and more celebrated as references that hold together fans of different subgenres.
And then most of the commercial blockbusters are sequels, remakes or adaptations.
Is there a possibility of special  episodes in the future?
I know it's way too early to be talking about this, but I'm really anxious for full sensory VR. are full dive VR depending on what you want to call it

Sad to see this series go. You had a great run! Any chance I could get an answer to this question: What will be the consequences of the death of medium-sized development studios? In the 90's and early 2000's there were a lot of medium sized devs that brought us a lot of advancements in gameplay and design. Nowadays we're left with big development houses making major titles, small development houses making mobile games and indie developers trying to get their foot in the door. What will this mean for the industry?
